By Rob D. Hawkins
I believe most doctors will tell you that it is rare when a patient has a lipid profile done and normal lipids levels are found. Most of us are simply too busy to pay much attention to take the steps necessary to achieve and maintain normal lipids and quite honestly when we gaze upon the dollar menu at our favorite fast food restaurant it is probably not something we considered. But perhaps it should be!
Plain and simple lipids are blood fats that if allowed to go unchecked can lead to a number of very serious conditions including heart attack, stroke, and atherosclerosis. These tiny molecules are poorly soluble in water thus needing help in moving through the bloodstream and are paired with less water soluble lipoproteins.
There are five lipoproteins categories listed in order of density. They are: chylomicrons, very low density lipoproteins (VLDL), intermediate density lipoprotein (IDL), low density lipoprotein (LDL), and high density lipoprotein (HDL).
When evaluating normal lipids we will taking a look at total cholesterol, triglycerides, LDL, and HDL.
Each of these reading has a slightly different significance and importance. Generally normal lipids are 230 or less for cholesterol; 150 or less for triglycerides; 130 or less for LDL; and 50 or more for HDL.
These numbers should be adjusted by 15 percent or so if a person has any one of a number of coronary disease risk factors are present. This list includes obesity, smoking, inactivity, high blood pressure, diabetes or being borderline diabetic, and age (over 45 years old for men and over 55 years old women).
When reading your lipid profile you doctor may choose to evaluate whether normal lipids levels exists by viewing the results as ratios. For example the most common way lipid risk for hardening of the arteries (atherosclerosis) is evaluated is by comparing total cholesterol to HDL. This ratio should not exceed 4.5 to 1. Another common evaluation method used is comparing LDL (bad cholesterol) to HDL (good cholesterol).This ratio should not be more than 2.5 to 1.
If my test confirm that I don't have the normal lipids reading I had hoped for what is the next step?
There are a number of steps your doctor will likely suggest. They are a low saturated fat diet high in soluble fiber; daily exercise; weight management; smoking cessation; reducing stress; and depending on the physician possibly a glass of red wine nightly.
It is worth mentioning that in order to lower both cholesterol and triglycerides a moderate amount of polyunsaturated fat may be required. The most healthful source of polyunsaturated fat is cold water fatty fish such as salmon and tuna.
If the above steps are not successful in achieving normal lipid levels then one of a number of cholesterol/blood fat reducing medications may be prescribed such as statin medications or prescription strength niacin.
Can supplements help?
Most current research supports this idea. Some of the best examples include certain B vitamins (B6,B12,folic acid); omega 3 fish oil high in DHA/EPA; and natural cholesterol reduction supplements containing phytosterols or policosanol.
